DROPS MOVE FOR

DEAN'S VIEWS FIRM
ON RULE QUESTION
Older Students Protested
When Council Cut Rules
2 Years Ago
A move launched by the Student
Council to re-establish freshman
regulations has been definitely dropped, it was learned today. Although
no reason was given by officials of
the student executive body for this
change of policy, it is believed that
resolution to drop the action was
taken after pressure was brought to
bear by executives of the University.
It is known that Dr. Joseph S.
Ames was opposed to the move,
while Dean Edward W. Berry has
frequently made public denunciations of any attempt to return the
freshman rules. However, when
the Student Council announced the
possibility of its disregarding executive opinion on the matter, officials at the University were said to
have expressed firm views on the
matter.
Will Yeto Any Resolution

Questioned on his disposition toward regulations, Dean Berry asserted that he would veto any resolution adopting freshman reguilations.
"Students should realize that
Hopkins is a college and not a playground," he said. "I do not intend
to tolerate the foolishness that some
students would introduce on the
Hopkins campus. They really don't
know what they want."
Were Revoked Two Years Ago

Freshman regulations, after a
practice of a number of years were
revoked by the Student Council two
years ago. The move was immediately followed by protests from
both older and younger members of
the campus although the complaint
of the former was more frequent
and organized.
In a recent poll taken by the Student Council a large majority of
the three hundred students who
voted favored the return of the

Interfraternity: Cup
Won By Tau Alpha Phi
Winning Fraternity Led With General Average of 78.1; Phi Kappa
Psi Is Second

The cup which is awarded annually to the fraternity on the Interfraternity Board which has the
best scholastic average for the year
went this year to Tau Alpha Phi
fraternity. The award was made
at the meeting of that board held
on Monday at noon.
Tau Alpha Phi led the members of the Board with a general
average of 78.1; Phi Kappa Psi being second with an average of 75.5.
The cup was awarded last year to
Alpha Tau Omega.
Ronald Brook and David A.
Huges were among those who
boosted the fraternity's rating.

Students Write Home
For $1,250 Annually
According to Palo Alto bankers,
the average student receives checks
from home which total $1,250 for
the year.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 24, 1931

B. A. Courses Compulsory
Dean Berry Advises
Pre-Medicoes
Despite protests entered, premedical students will be required
to register for all courses that
have been made compulsory for
candidates for the Bachelor of
Arts degree, Edward W. Berry,
Dean, declared yesterday.
Most of the requisite courses
deplored by pre-medical students
are listed under the recently altered curriculum.

1932 Edition

GOUCHER COLLEGE
TO AWARD DEGREES
Mrs. Herbert Hoover Will Be
One of Four Women
Honored

Public Opinion
By Hyman Levin
From not only its scholastic
standing in the educational world,
courses offered, and the faculty
maintained, but also from its student body and its activities on the
campus is public opinion molded in
regard to a college.
From what occurrences that have
befallen Homewood during the past
several months, the Johns Hopkins University doubtlessly must
present a totally sad picture to the
citizens of Baltimore.
Perhaps the three events which
have given the public an entirely
unsavory conception of the University this year are: (1) the alleged
tearing down of a bronze statue by
rioting Hopkins students prior to
the annual Maryland-Jays football
classic ;(2) the wholesale suspension
by the Student Council of more than
150 underclassmen for failure to
attend compulsory weekly assemblies; (3) the snowball battle outside the Alumni Memorial Hall, in
which a graduate student injured
three students with air-rifle shots.

the college shall not deteriorate into
the usual type "rah-rah" institution. Though much has been done
to elevate the undergraduate departments, there is still a tremendously vital need to teach the undergraduate the responsibilities he
has toward the University as a
whole.
The president of the University
once remarked that the initial task
is to transform the entering student; fresh from high school, from
a boy into a man in as short a time
as possible. Dr. Ames's statement
bears great weight, for it is obvious,
the college here cannot possibly be
made truly different from and better than the usual undergraduate
school if the change is not made in
the new college student immediately. A college of boys assuredly
cannot make as great progress as a
college of men.
Undergraduates must realiz.e that
whatever they do they are at all
times being Subject to the stern observation by those on the outside of
the campus, even more so than by
those on.
Perhaps—who knows ?—such occurrences as have occurred at
HomeWood recently, may have
easily caused more than one indifidual interested in the johns Hopkins to finally decide to withdraw
the University's name from his
will. Such moves are blows to the
institution. Money is needed, and
needed badly.

What does it all mean? Ask any
fair co-ed and she will tell you it
means love note day. This old Kansas Kustom, one of the bright spots
of the year to many of the Wesleyan maidens, is sponsored by the Y.
W. C. A. It is the time when every
girl in school lets all her friends
know just how much she appreciates their friendship. Some notes
are long, some are short, some serious, others in a humorous vein,
but the important thing is to start
the writing early, because it soon
becomes evident that the longer one
writes, the more friends one thinks
of to write to.

ville Women'Wednesday Night
"The Brat," a three-act comedy,
was presented by members of the
public speaking and dramatic class
of the Maryland College for Women last Wednesday night.
The cast, coached by Miss Katerine MacLean, instructor of the
class, numbered eleven students.
Miss Ginevra Kraus of Popstown,
Pa., took the leading role. The cast
includes: Miss Vashti Hodges,
Emily Draper, Lyda Parker, Elizabeth Branner, Beatrice Phoman,
Letitia Whedon, Helen Anderson,
Cynthia Tiffany, Alpha Penrod
and Elizabeth Stacks.

Students at Columbia U. are
reveling in a discovery recently
brought to light Even Columbia
professors fidget nervously and bluff
through unfamiliar questions when
they are , faced with an exam.
Thomas Beer, noted author, had
prepared a test on general knowledge which 25 college students flatly "busted." The Columbia "Spectator" then requested that the professors undergo a similar test. Every
professor flunked, the highest mark
being 55.1 per cent. The highest
mark among students who took the
test at the same time was 46 per
cent. Student ecstasy was heightened when it was revealed that the
highest students' mark exceeded
the lowest professors' grade by 3.3
per cent.

state lacrosse competition with
eight pointe.
Guild and D. Kelly, both of the
Jay twelve, are tied for third
place with six goals each. Stone
follows them in fourth place with
five markers. Tied with four
other stickmen in fifth place in the
scoring list is Beeler, another Jay
player, who has tossed in four
goals so far.

Serious
Paganism
Sees
Threat To Best In Western
Civilization
RENAISSANCE MADE
MORAL SUBORDINATE
Famous As Philosopher and
Historian, Dr. Ferrero
Was Roosevelts' Guest
Modern life is half Christian
and half pagan, is the belief of Dr.
Guglielmo Ferrero, famous historian and philosopher, as expressed
yesterday before a large audience
in Latrobe Hall, under the James
Schouler Lectureship. The topic
of the speaker's address was
"Christianity and Paganism in
Modern Civilization".
Christian Morality

Dr. Ferrero describes the growth
of paganism and its serious threat
against the best in western civilization. "In the middle ages Europe
was a theocracy, as still today are
the Musselmen lands and many
eastern countries," the speaker
claimed. "And because Christian
morality did not permit Europe to
go to spleep", he continued, "Christian theocracy of the middle ages
did not become crystallized like the
theocracies of the Musselmen transformed itself, with an increased activity, step by step, into the wonderful present civilization, European-American. "Christian morality accomplished this mainly by
subjecting the power and the state
to morality", he said.
Effects of the Renaissance

Dr. Ferrero went on to show how
fro mthe sixteenth century onwards
the great political, scientific, and
military progress brought on by the
Renaissance was accompanied by a
growing tendency in all lands towards making the state the supreme power, and to the subordination of morality to power, which
is the negative of Christianity.
Growth of Paganism
"Within the last half century, the
world has become more paganized", emphasized the noted historian and philosopher, -and on the
day western civilization is again
subordinated to a pagan theocratic
conception of the state, western
civilization will have fallen into irreparable decadence". Dr. Ferrero
concluded with the explanation of
the great necessity of calling attention to this phenomena in order that
a vigorous force be put forward in
defense of Christian morality.
Historian and Philosopher

Dr. Guglielmo Ferrero's first
volume of his great work, "The
Greatness and Decline of Rome,'
stamped him as one of the world's
greatest historians. His work, "Between the Old World and the
New", expressing valuable philosophical theories, places him in the
line of great philosophers. Some
of his more successful works are
"The Young Europe," "The Militarism", and "The Thircl Rome",
published in America as "The Seven
Vices".
Roosevelt's Guest

Theodore Roosevelt, then President, invited Dr. Ferrero to come
to the United States. Dr. Ferrero
came in 1908 and lived at the White
House during most of his stay. It
was at this time that President
Roosevelt declared him to be "the
world's greatest living historian".
While in America he lectured before many of our leading universities.

Some doubt looms as to whether
Hopkins will be represented at the
annual relay carnival held by the
University of Pennsylvania.
Captain Lockard and Oz Linck,
veterans of last year's quartet, are
both suffering from pulled muscles.
The injuries were sustained in the
recent meet at Haverford College.
Chassin and Jung, both of whom
have seen service in the Relays, are
in only fair shape. The reserve
material, from which Coach Hambleton may draw a man to fill in a
vacancy, includes Coburn and
Perry, hurdlers, and Zepp and
Verlin, half milers, none of whom
are experienced men.
Monday afternoon, at 4 o'clock,
an Inter-class track meet will be
held at the field. A full schedule
of events will be run off with full
distances being covered in each.
Entries may be made at the field,
until Saturday, inclusive, and
everyone is invited to participate.
Points will be aggregated according to classes.
Handicaps To Be Given

Handicaps will be given inexperienced men, although they will
not be so great as those meted out
in the recent Handicap meet. The
idea in cutting the size of the
handicaps is to promote interest in
the finishes of the various events.
No varsity meet is scheduled for
this week end, so the meet affords
the competition, necessary to the
conditioning of the men. Also the
meet will serve to give Coach Hambleton a line on his junior varsity
squad, which meets Gilman Country School next Friday.
All managers have been asked to
report to the field, next Monday.

REPORTED 'AROUSED'
OVER 'INDIFFERENCE'
Controversy Rife Over Date
Of Annual Tussle; No
Agreement Yet
Despite efforts by athletic authorities at Homewood and the
alumni branch of the Vargity Club,
no mutual agreement has been
reached on the date of the St.
Johns-Johns Hopkins lacrosse tussle, controversy over which has
been continuing for many months.
Todie Riggs Quoted

"St. John's will not play Hopkins on June 6 even if it means
that the locals (St. John's) will
have to give up any chance they
may have representing this country
in the international games with
Canada in Baltimore this summer",
Todie Riggs, director of athletics at
St. John's, is quoted in the "Views
and Chatter on Sports" column by
E. M. Jackson, Jr., sports editor of
The Evening Capital, of Annapolis,
Md.
Mr. Jackson further declares:
St. John's is thoroughly disgusted with
the way Hopkins has acted and from an
angle of self-respect could not be obliged
to meet the Jays on June 6, the date the
Baltimoreans are now endeavoring to force
the locals after twice breaking faith on
what appeared definite dates with the Annapolitans. Sports Writer Assumes

Under no circumstances will St.
John's reopen negotiations with
Hopkins, it is believed by the Evening Capital sports editor, unless the
Homewood team decides to accept
"one of the several dates offered
and in which there is no conflict or
near games".
In his column Mr. Jackson makes
this declaration:
Hopkins, according to reports, expects
the committee which will select the team
to represent this country against the Canadians to demand a playoff. They expect
it will bring St. John's and themselves
together—thus why bother phout scheduling a game.

Riggs Reported 'Aroused'

Mr. Riggs is said to be "much
aroused over Hopkins' indifferent
attitude".
The Annapolis paper's sports editor contends that it would be better
for St. John's "to lose the privilege of representing this nation
than to lose its self-respect".
What Hopkins 'Feels'

In his concluding argument, the
writer declares:
Hopkins apparently feels that St. John's
is a better team than they care .to meet
right now. In other words they see 'the
papering on the wall'. An excuse that
they cannot play two games in one week
is rather silly. St. John's, starting today,
(Monday) will play five games in eight
days. Despite these risks the Orange and
Black have been getting better results
than Hopkins.

Whether
St. John's• and Hopkins
• .•
will. meet. at lacrosse this season
cannot be ascertained.
•
.Three Dates Offered
Apri1.18, 25 and June 6 had been
offered- the Annapolis institution
when the schedule was being arranged for this season. In rejecting.,theSe offers by Homewood officials, the Crabtown authorities asserted, it is said, that the two April
dates were too early in the season
and,that the June date was too late
in the season and too near to graduation time.
Following this, St. John's offered
May 2 as the lone suitable date for
the annual clash. However, Hopkins was forced not to accept the
date because of a game, scheduled
many months previous, with Princeton. To meet the Annapolis twelve
the day after was termed"a physical impossibility".
Compromise Suggested

The Athletic Board here, in a
compromise, suggested that St.
John's play Princeton on May 1 and
Hopkins on May 2; Hopkins,
Princeton on May 23 and University of Maryland on June 6. The
plan, branded by many as absurd
and unfair to all concerned, was
not accepted.

Spring Showing

The Student Council's ruling in
regard to "breaking up" of freshman and sophomore banquets will
be enforced stringently, declared
Francis Warlow, president of the
student governing body.
The ruling provides that the
freshman banquets must not be disturbed by unruly sophomores, and
the sophomores should not be subject to any serious outrages of the
freshmen when the former's feast
is in progress. This ruling, it is
said, went into effect in 1928 when
many casualties as a result of the
banquets demanded some regulation among both classes.

DEAN'S VIEWS FIRM
ON RULE QUESTION
Older Students Protested
When Council Cut Rules
2 Years Ago
A move launched by the Student
Council to re-establish freshman
regulations has been definitely dropped, it was learned today. Although
no reason was given by officials of
the student executive body for this
change of policy, it is believed that
resolution to drop the action was
taken after pressure was brought to
bear by executives of the University.
It is known that Dr. Joseph S.
Ames was opposed to the move,
while Dean Edward W. Berry has
frequently made public denunciations of any attempt to return the
freshman rules. However, when
the Student Council announced the
possibility of its disregarding executive opinion on the matter, officials at the University were said to
have expressed firm views on the
matter.
Will Yeto Any Resolution

Questioned on his disposition toward regulations, Dean Berry asserted that he would veto any resolution adopting freshman reguilations.
"Students should realize that
Hopkins is a college and not a playground," he said. "I do not intend
to tolerate the foolishness that some
students would introduce on the
Hopkins campus. They really don't
know what they want."
Were Revoked Two Years Ago

Freshman regulations, after a
practice of a number of years were
revoked by the Student Council two
years ago. The move was immediately followed by protests from
both older and younger members of
the campus although the complaint
of the former was more frequent
and organized.
In a recent poll taken by the Student Council a large majority of
the three hundred students who
voted favored the return of the

Interfraternity: Cup
Won By Tau Alpha Phi
Winning Fraternity Led With General Average of 78.1; Phi Kappa
Psi Is Second

The cup which is awarded annually to the fraternity on the Interfraternity Board which has the
best scholastic average for the year
went this year to Tau Alpha Phi
fraternity. The award was made
at the meeting of that board held
on Monday at noon.
Tau Alpha Phi led the members of the Board with a general
average of 78.1; Phi Kappa Psi being second with an average of 75.5.
The cup was awarded last year to
Alpha Tau Omega.
Ronald Brook and David A.
Huges were among those who
boosted the fraternity's rating.

Students Write Home
For $1,250 Annually
According to Palo Alto bankers,
the average student receives checks
from home which total $1,250 for
the year.

GOUCHER COLLEGE
TO AWARD DEGREES
Mrs. Herbert Hoover Will Be
One of Four Women
Honored

Public Opinion
By Hyman Levin
From not only its scholastic
standing in the educational world,
courses offered, and the faculty
maintained, but also from its student body and its activities on the
campus is public opinion molded in
regard to a college.
From what occurrences that have
befallen Homewood during the past
several months, the Johns Hopkins University doubtlessly must
present a totally sad picture to the
citizens of Baltimore.
Perhaps the three events which
have given the public an entirely
unsavory conception of the University this year are: (1) the alleged
tearing down of a bronze statue by
rioting Hopkins students prior to
the annual Maryland-Jays football
classic ;(2) the wholesale suspension
by the Student Council of more than
150 underclassmen for failure to
attend compulsory weekly assemblies; (3) the snowball battle outside the Alumni Memorial Hall, in
which a graduate student injured
three students with air-rifle shots.

the college shall not deteriorate into
the usual type "rah-rah" institution. Though much has been done
to elevate the undergraduate departments, there is still a tremendously vital need to teach the undergraduate the responsibilities he
has toward the University as a
whole.
The president of the University
once remarked that the initial task
is to transform the entering student; fresh from high school, from
a boy into a man in as short a time
as possible. Dr. Ames's statement
bears great weight, for it is obvious,
the college here cannot possibly be
made truly different from and better than the usual undergraduate
school if the change is not made in
the new college student immediately. A college of boys assuredly
cannot make as great progress as a
college of men.
Undergraduates must realiz.e that
whatever they do they are at all
times being Subject to the stern observation by those on the outside of
the campus, even more so than by
those on.
Perhaps—who knows ?—such occurrences as have occurred at
HomeWood recently, may have
easily caused more than one indifidual interested in the johns Hopkins to finally decide to withdraw
the University's name from his
will. Such moves are blows to the
institution. Money is needed, and
needed badly.

Comedy Was Presented By Luther-

What does it all mean? Ask any
fair co-ed and she will tell you it
means love note day. This old Kansas Kustom, one of the bright spots
of the year to many of the Wesleyan maidens, is sponsored by the Y.
W. C. A. It is the time when every
girl in school lets all her friends
know just how much she appreciates their friendship. Some notes
are long, some are short, some serious, others in a humorous vein,
but the important thing is to start
the writing early, because it soon
becomes evident that the longer one
writes, the more friends one thinks
of to write to.

ville Women'Wednesday Night
"The Brat," a three-act comedy,
was presented by members of the
public speaking and dramatic class
of the Maryland College for Women last Wednesday night.
The cast, coached by Miss Katerine MacLean, instructor of the
class, numbered eleven students.
Miss Ginevra Kraus of Popstown,
Pa., took the leading role. The cast
includes: Miss Vashti Hodges,
Emily Draper, Lyda Parker, Elizabeth Branner, Beatrice Phoman,
Letitia Whedon, Helen Anderson,
Cynthia Tiffany, Alpha Penrod
and Elizabeth Stacks.

Students at Columbia U. are
reveling in a discovery recently
brought to light Even Columbia
professors fidget nervously and bluff
through unfamiliar questions when
they are , faced with an exam.
Thomas Beer, noted author, had
prepared a test on general knowledge which 25 college students flatly "busted." The Columbia "Spectator" then requested that the professors undergo a similar test. Every
professor flunked, the highest mark
being 55.1 per cent. The highest
mark among students who took the
test at the same time was 46 per
cent. Student ecstasy was heightened when it was revealed that the
highest students' mark exceeded
the lowest professors' grade by 3.3
per cent.

Darrell, Turnbull
Leading Scorers
Darrell and Turnbull, of Hopkins, are tied for second place in
lacrosse scoring honors with Steiber, of Maryland, and Moncure, of
Navy. Each have garnered seven
points. Ed Ronkin, Maryland's
attack star leads the 25 scorers in
state lacrosse competition with
eight pointe.
Guild and D. Kelly, both of the
Jay twelve, are tied for third
place with six goals each. Stone
follows them in fourth place with
five markers. Tied with four
other stickmen in fifth place in the
scoring list is Beeler, another Jay
player, who has tossed in four
goals so far.

Serious
Paganism
Sees
Threat To Best In Western
Civilization
RENAISSANCE MADE
MORAL SUBORDINATE
Famous As Philosopher and
Historian, Dr. Ferrero
Was Roosevelts' Guest
Modern life is half Christian
and half pagan, is the belief of Dr.
Guglielmo Ferrero, famous historian and philosopher, as expressed
yesterday before a large audience
in Latrobe Hall, under the James
Schouler Lectureship. The topic
of the speaker's address was
"Christianity and Paganism in
Modern Civilization".
Christian Morality

Dr. Ferrero describes the growth
of paganism and its serious threat
against the best in western civilization. "In the middle ages Europe
was a theocracy, as still today are
the Musselmen lands and many
eastern countries," the speaker
claimed. "And because Christian
morality did not permit Europe to
go to spleep", he continued, "Christian theocracy of the middle ages
did not become crystallized like the
theocracies of the Musselmen transformed itself, with an increased activity, step by step, into the wonderful present civilization, European-American. "Christian morality accomplished this mainly by
subjecting the power and the state
to morality", he said.
Effects of the Renaissance

Dr. Ferrero went on to show how
fro mthe sixteenth century onwards
the great political, scientific, and
military progress brought on by the
Renaissance was accompanied by a
growing tendency in all lands towards making the state the supreme power, and to the subordination of morality to power, which
is the negative of Christianity.
Growth of Paganism
"Within the last half century, the
world has become more paganized", emphasized the noted historian and philosopher, -and on the
day western civilization is again
subordinated to a pagan theocratic
conception of the state, western
civilization will have fallen into irreparable decadence". Dr. Ferrero
concluded with the explanation of
the great necessity of calling attention to this phenomena in order that
a vigorous force be put forward in
defense of Christian morality.
Historian and Philosopher

Dr. Guglielmo Ferrero's first
volume of his great work, "The
Greatness and Decline of Rome,'
stamped him as one of the world's
greatest historians. His work, "Between the Old World and the
New", expressing valuable philosophical theories, places him in the
line of great philosophers. Some
of his more successful works are
"The Young Europe," "The Militarism", and "The Thircl Rome",
published in America as "The Seven
Vices".
Roosevelt's Guest

Theodore Roosevelt, then President, invited Dr. Ferrero to come
to the United States. Dr. Ferrero
came in 1908 and lived at the White
House during most of his stay. It
was at this time that President
Roosevelt declared him to be "the
world's greatest living historian".
While in America he lectured before many of our leading universities.

Jay Racqueters On

Pennsylvania Trip
June Week Match
Will

Meet Gettysburg Today And Yellott, Chairman, Also Announces
Haverford Tomorrow; May
Nocturnal Sail On S. S. Annapolis
Schedule Considered Heavy
With Melody, Moonshine And
Dancing

Some doubt looms as to whether
Hopkins will be represented at the
annual relay carnival held by the
University of Pennsylvania.
Captain Lockard and Oz Linck,
veterans of last year's quartet, are
both suffering from pulled muscles.
The injuries were sustained in the
recent meet at Haverford College.
Chassin and Jung, both of whom
have seen service in the Relays, are
in only fair shape. The reserve
material, from which Coach Hambleton may draw a man to fill in a
vacancy, includes Coburn and
Perry, hurdlers, and Zepp and
Verlin, half milers, none of whom
are experienced men.
Monday afternoon, at 4 o'clock,
an Inter-class track meet will be
held at the field. A full schedule
of events will be run off with full
distances being covered in each.
Entries may be made at the field,
until Saturday, inclusive, and
everyone is invited to participate.
Points will be aggregated according to classes.
Handicaps To Be Given

Handicaps will be given inexperienced men, although they will
not be so great as those meted out
in the recent Handicap meet. The
idea in cutting the size of the
handicaps is to promote interest in
the finishes of the various events.
No varsity meet is scheduled for
this week end, so the meet affords
the competition, necessary to the
conditioning of the men. Also the
meet will serve to give Coach Hambleton a line on his junior varsity
squad, which meets Gilman Country School next Friday.
All managers have been asked to
report to the field, next Monday.

Made During 1923 Season

REPORTED 'AROUSED'
OVER 'INDIFFERENCE'
Controversy Rife Over Date
Of Annual Tussle; No
Agreement Yet
Despite efforts by athletic authorities at Homewood and the
alumni branch of the Vargity Club,
no mutual agreement has been
reached on the date of the St.
Johns-Johns Hopkins lacrosse tussle, controversy over which has
been continuing for many months.
Todie Riggs Quoted

"St. John's will not play Hopkins on June 6 even if it means
that the locals (St. John's) will
have to give up any chance they
may have representing this country
in the international games with
Canada in Baltimore this summer",
Todie Riggs, director of athletics at
St. John's, is quoted in the "Views
and Chatter on Sports" column by
E. M. Jackson, Jr., sports editor of
The Evening Capital, of Annapolis,
Md.
Mr. Jackson further declares:
St. John's is thoroughly disgusted with
the way Hopkins has acted and from an
angle of self-respect could not be obliged
to meet the Jays on June 6, the date the
Baltimoreans are now endeavoring to force
the locals after twice breaking faith on
what appeared definite dates with the Annapolitans. Sports Writer Assumes

Under no circumstances will St.
John's reopen negotiations with
Hopkins, it is believed by the Evening Capital sports editor, unless the
Homewood team decides to accept
"one of the several dates offered
and in which there is no conflict or
near games".
In his column Mr. Jackson makes
this declaration:
Hopkins, according to reports, expects
the committee which will select the team
to represent this country against the Canadians to demand a playoff. They expect
it will bring St. John's and themselves
together—thus why bother phout scheduling a game.

Riggs Reported 'Aroused'

Mr. Riggs is said to be "much
aroused over Hopkins' indifferent
attitude".
The Annapolis paper's sports editor contends that it would be better
for St. John's "to lose the privilege of representing this nation
than to lose its self-respect".
What Hopkins 'Feels'

In his concluding argument, the
writer declares:
Hopkins apparently feels that St. John's
is a better team than they care .to meet
right now. In other words they see 'the
papering on the wall'. An excuse that
they cannot play two games in one week
is rather silly. St. John's, starting today,
(Monday) will play five games in eight
days. Despite these risks the Orange and
Black have been getting better results
than Hopkins.

Whether
St. John's• and Hopkins
• .•
will. meet. at lacrosse this season
cannot be ascertained.
•
.Three Dates Offered
Apri1.18, 25 and June 6 had been
offered- the Annapolis institution
when the schedule was being arranged for this season. In rejecting.,theSe offers by Homewood officials, the Crabtown authorities asserted, it is said, that the two April
dates were too early in the season
and,that the June date was too late
in the season and too near to graduation time.
Following this, St. John's offered
May 2 as the lone suitable date for
the annual clash. However, Hopkins was forced not to accept the
date because of a game, scheduled
many months previous, with Princeton. To meet the Annapolis twelve
the day after was termed"a physical impossibility".
Compromise Suggested

The Athletic Board here, in a
compromise, suggested that St.
John's play Princeton on May 1 and
Hopkins on May 2; Hopkins,
Princeton on May 23 and University of Maryland on June 6. The
plan, branded by many as absurd
and unfair to all concerned, was
not accepted.

Spring Showing

The Student Council's ruling in
regard to "breaking up" of freshman and sophomore banquets will
be enforced stringently, declared
Francis Warlow, president of the
student governing body.
The ruling provides that the
freshman banquets must not be disturbed by unruly sophomores, and
the sophomores should not be subject to any serious outrages of the
freshmen when the former's feast
is in progress. This ruling, it is
said, went into effect in 1928 when
many casualties as a result of the
banquets demanded some regulation among both classes.
